data.text: Tubes or Tubeless Tires for Bikepacking: What Is Your Preference?

Hello everyone. Tubes or tubeless? What's your preference? Which of the two so you prefer? Why and why not? I'm still using the stock tires on my priority 600x which are the WTB ranger tires. Also, are there tires you can recommend as an all arounder tire? I've been looking at the maxxis ardent, aggressor, and rekon tires. I hear great things about maxxis in general, so figured I'd start with that brand.
People who get flats, like lower pressure , and do trendy stuff like tubeless. They also like posting about it on the internet. You‚Äôll see.
data.author: Tom Cavan

data.text: "trendy stuff like tubeless" lol. You act as if it's a new thing. I've been running tubeless tires since 2003.
data.author: Dustin Schulten

data.text: interesting lol
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: : my incidents of flats have gone down to nearly zero since I first changed over nearly 5 years ago. In fact, I have had only one flat and that was at the beginning before I knrew that the sealant must be refilled now and then. I ride in the desert Southwest of the USA, by the way. Everything in our trails wants to poke holes in you or your tires.
data.author: Gilbert Moreno

data.text: : BOOOOMMMM!
data.author: Gilbert Moreno

data.text: probably a 1x gravel bike too.
data.author: Tom Cavan

data.text: yeah. Technology is rad.
data.author: Dustin Schulten

data.text: I like Schwalbe Mondial ( with tubes) as wide as your frame allows.
data.author: Tom Cavan

data.text: I'll check em out.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: I like the sound of these, but do they come in 29" cause I don't see them in that size.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: yes. They may list them as 622/700c/28‚Äù/29‚Äù. They all fit the 622 rim. 29‚Äù is just a marketing term for wider 622 tires.
data.author: Tom Cavan

data.text: You need tubeless ready rims to go tubeless, so it‚Äôs not just the tires.
data.author: Cheryl Leskiw

data.text: yeah, my rims are tubeless compatible. I'm not sure if I'd have to add rim tape or not, but they are supposed to be tubeless ready.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: Tubeless, Maxxis Ikons are hard to beat.
data.author: Dustin Schulten

data.text: Tubeless üíØ Rides better, less punctures Check the Maxxis Ikon
data.author: James Folsom

data.text: The only people who run tubes are also afraid of their own shadow. Its proven technology, I've been running tubeless on mtbs since 2006 and my cross bike since 2014. Zero issues that wouldn't have been an issue with running tubes. Getting it set up is tricky if you don't understand how it works but bike shops can do that for you
data.author: Will Wells

data.text: nice generalization of people. üôÑ
data.author: Diane Farley

data.text: tbh as someone just getting into this, this is what's stopping me. I just don't want problems when I'm out there. Tubes seem easy as hell. Dealing with the sealant, and seating it, etc. I've heard it's a pain. But I do want tubeless. I guess I'm scared of my own shadow üòÇ
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: truth hurts huh?
data.author: Devin Cutter

data.text: as I said. No problem you could get with tubeless wouldn't be a problem with tubes. If you have one of those problems, you can stick a tube in just like you normally would. It's not hard. I still take a tube with me on long rides because a backup is never a bad idea but that doesn't mean that tubes are better or more reliable in ANY way. It's the last ditch attempt to get you home for a reason. The last option is always the worst option
data.author: Will Wells

data.text: nah just rudeness
data.author: Rudy Zamora

data.text: WTF ever
data.author: Diane Farley

data.text: So where have you been?
data.author: Lars Bengtsson

data.text: most of Europe, including your homeland, not that it matters, there are plenty of spiky objects on the streets of Bristol that will shred a tyre to pieces. Again, no single puncture I've had with tubeless wouldn't have been a puncture with tubes. A lot of punctures I've had with tubes wouldn't have happened with tubeless. I feel like I'm repeating myself
data.author: Will Wells

data.text: I cycled 11 000 km to Senegal without a flat. If I got a flat the local bike repair man could fix it in a couple of minutes if I dont want to do it myself. Flats is not even a problem if you have good tyres.
data.author: Lars Bengtsson

data.text: tell me more about these non existant puncture proof tyres
data.author: Will Wells

data.text: actually, don't
data.author: Will Wells

data.text: I dont think you are open minded enough to understand it anyway üòÇüòÇ
data.author: Lars Bengtsson

data.text: To put it into context, I'm a professional bicycle mechanic. I've fixed around 10,000 punctures, many of those have been so called "puncture resistant" tyres such as schwalbe marathon plus, continental gatorskin hardshell. If these tyres are so perfect, why am i fixing punctures on them daily? My mind is open, yours is stuck in the 1990s
data.author: Will Wells

data.text: I run tubes and haven‚Äôt had a single problem in a year and I ride some rough terrain almost daily. Lots of road travel too. As long as it works, I‚Äôm not ‚Äúfixing‚Äù it.
data.author: Diane Farley

data.text: you think pretty highly of yourself. When you have to toss around your credentials do people just fall at your feet? Get over yourself. There are lots of people doing just fine without you looking down your nose at them.
data.author: Diane Farley

data.text: , tubeless not only means punctures are rare, but more importantly, you can run correct tyre pressure. This means more comfort, more grip and more speed. So they are a win, win, win, win solution. Best improvement to bike riding in my lifetime.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: , regardless of how good your tyres are, you will get pinch flats unless you ride with tyres pumped too hard. Tubeless solves this problem. Meaning punctures are a rarity, your bike is soooo much more comfortable with more grip and rolls faster to boot.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: , context matters and listening to folk with experience can be extremely informative. Doing just fine with tubes is like doing just fine with any 19th century tech despite advances since.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence

data.text: Run whatever the hell you want. Reality is that if it rolls down the road, gravel path, or singletrack it's working. Most people who run tubeless still carry a tube and those who run tubes usually carry a patch kit.
data.author: Steven Baker

data.text: For performance on the bike during the ride tubeless. For ease of maintenance and keeping it more simple tubes. Tubeless you need to put in the work at home while not riding at times. I run tubeless and enjoy maintaing the bike for best riding day experience. If you are time straped overall might be best to stay with tubes.
data.author: Nbs Guy

data.text: There are some major douche sheriffs in these comments. Lord. So much elitism.
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: Tubes in Panaracer Gravelkings+ Why? Cause I‚Äôm scared of novelties when I‚Äôm in the middle of nowhere :D
data.author: Tjal Num

data.text: Tubes for my road and commuter bikes. Tubeless for the rest
data.author: Martin Pont

data.text: I've been riding tubeless on all my gravel and tour bikes without any flats going on 6 years. I still bring extra tubes and at least one tire when I tour. There is a learning curve running tubeless setup but otherwise I love the peace of mind when riding tubeless setup.
data.author: Dave Becker-Ellison

data.text: Tubeless for mtb...currently still have tubes on gravel bike
data.author: Brandi Jackson Hodges

data.text: I haven't had a flat with tubless since 1965. My bike weighs 9 lbs less without tubes. My bike goes 20mph faster tubless. Tubless attracts the opposite sex, that's the only drawback since I already have someone.
data.author: Brett Jensen

data.text: Tubeless for me. 40mm wide tires and 40psi are my cutoffs though. Below 40mm and above 40psi too large a percentage of air escapes before holes seal for my liking. Tubeless is like sex, it just feels better without the thin layer in the way. Just way less risk.
data.author: Alex Helling

data.text: I just went tubeless a month ago and I can honestly say I'm never going back. Nothing better than the feel of riding a good tubeless set up....that said, riding a bad tubeless set up sounds like the stuff of nightmares. Let your lbs set it up. I'm riding 38 mm Gravelkings Super Slick. If you get tubeless use the Silca tire pressure calculator to determine the right pressure for the surface you're on.
data.author: Trey Freeman

data.text: I always buy whatever tubeless tires I can find on sale. In the terrain where I ride everything wants to poke holes in you and your tires. Sharp rocks make quick work of wearing down any tire, so I always go for the least expensive.
data.author: Gilbert Moreno

data.text: Continental race kings, tubeless. I carry a tube always just in case but I've only gotten a flat tubeless once compared a running tubes where it can happen more often
data.author: Nicholas Wiltshire

data.text: Thanks for the responses everyone. Appreciate it.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: I've run both tubed and tubeless and don't have a preferance. I have schwable marathon mondial evo and find then an excellent all purpose tire.
data.author: Geoff Currie

data.text: Tubeless only has advantages. Smoother rolling, much less flats, you can go lower in pressure, making the ride more comfortable, you can just put a tube like usual if you really need, ... . I ride tubeless since 2009 on MTB and since 2019 on my roadbike, I'll never go back. When bikepacking or touring you should still take spare tubes with you. In the off case you really need to fix your tires and don't have a shop with compressor nearby you will have to use them. And take a schrader to presta converter with you, so a car or motorcycle shop can inflate your tires if needed. My all time favourite tubeless tires on MTB for all conditions are specialized fast trak, they really roll very soft, low rolling resistance and good grip on most terain.
data.author: Gert Pellin

data.text: thanks!
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: I run tubeless but then also put a tube in. Like double the safety and reliability
data.author: Willie Fabins

data.text: I tried that when the brand slime has their inner tubes with sealant already in it and afterwards when schwalbe first came with the tubes with replaceable valve core, making it possible to inject sealant. But it doesn't work. I had almost as much fatal punctures as if I would use the regular inner tubes. Also you don't have any of the other advantages you have with tubeless, being no snakebite punctures, being able to run a lower pressure and the lower rolling resistance because of removing the layer friction.
data.author: Gert Pellin

data.text: I rode 2400km, half gravel half tar. Zero punctures. Afterwards I inspected my tyres and estimate I saw about 50 potential punctures tubeless sealant saved me from. You make your own choice.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: Tubeless is 100% superior.
data.author: Tom Hughes

data.text: Tubeless üôÇ I use continental tyres, so far the best
data.author: Sherry Buzzalong

data.text: what tires of continental do you use? I have continental cross king on one of my mountainbikes now. Rolling and grip are good but I have the feeling they don't really seal to the rim as good as other tires I used.
data.author: Gert Pellin

data.text: When gears were addd to bikes I'm sure folk shook their fists and wrote letters to bike magazines claiming single speed bikes were just fine, so there was no need for any of this new fangled derailleur nonsense. üòÉ Now they complain about disc brakes and tubeless tyres.
data.author: Jeremy Lawrence
